lectures.title: DU FBS Accounting – Lecture 1
lectures.topics: Introduction to Accounting, Users of Accounting Information, Transaction, Basis of Accounting, Accounts

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct sequence of steps in the recording process?
questions.explanation: The correct sequence in the accounting recording process is: 1. **Analyzing** transactions 2. **Journalizing** entries 3. **Posting** to ledger accounts

questions.question: The term "double entry systems" refers to:

options.C: Use of two journals and one ledger
options.D: Recording double effects of each transaction
options.E: Use of cash book and journal

questions.explanation: Under the **double-entry system**, every transaction has **two aspects**: a **debit** and a **credit** of equal amount. This ensures that the accounting equation remains balanced and that the dual effect of each transaction is properly recorded.

questions.question: Accounting:

options.A: Is a process involving identification, measurement, recording and reporting of information
options.B: Concerns economic information about a business entity
options.C: Provides information for use in financial decision making
options.D: All of the above answers are correct
options.E: None of the above answers are correct

questions.explanation: Accounting is a **comprehensive process** that: - Identifies, measures, records, and reports financial information - Focuses on economic information about an entity - Supports **decision making** by internal and external users Since all three statements (A, B, and C) are true, the correct answer is **D: All of the above**.

questions.question: Which of the following is an internal user?
questions.explanation: **Management** (managers, directors, executives) work **inside** the organisation and use detailed accounting information for planning, controlling, and decision making, so they are **internal users**. > Note: In many textbooks, employees may also be treated as internal users, but in this lecture set and exam context, “internal users” is used mainly for management-level decision makers.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about users of accounting information is incorrect?

options.D: Shareholders of a company are external users

questions.explanation: In this lecture and exam context: - **Management** is internal (A – correct). - **Tax authorities, shareholders, and creditors** are all external (B, D, E – correct). - The **incorrect** statement is **C**, because employees are being classified as **external users** of published financial information rather than part of management.

questions.question: Which of the following expense does not require cash?
questions.explanation: **Depreciation** is a **non-cash expense** that allocates the cost of a long-term asset over its useful life. No cash is paid when depreciation expense is recorded.

questions.question: Which of the following events is NOT recorded in accounting records?

options.B: A cash investment is made into the business
options.C: The owner withdraws cash for personal use

questions.explanation: The **termination of an employee** is a personnel decision that does not, by itself, involve a monetary transaction, so it is **not recorded** in the accounting records. All other options involve measurable financial effects.

questions.question: Which of the following events is not a transaction?

options.A: Unpaid salaries for the accounting period
options.B: Service revenue earned but not received
options.C: Increase in the value of inventory
options.E: Utilities bill received for the period but not paid

questions.explanation: A simple **increase in the value of inventory** due to price changes is not a recordable transaction if no purchase or sale occurs. The other options involve obligations, losses, or revenues that are recognised in the accounts.

questions.question: For which item is cash flow not required?
questions.explanation: **Bad debt written off** is an **adjusting entry** that removes uncollectible receivables from the books. No cash is paid or received at the time of the write-off.

questions.question: For which transaction is cash spent?
questions.explanation: **Prepaid rent** involves paying cash **in advance** for future rent periods, so there is an actual cash outflow. Depreciation, amortisation, and stock dividends are non-cash entries. A **cash discount** is a reduction in the amount paid, not a separate cash outflow.

questions.question: Which one is an example of internal transaction?
questions.explanation: The **use of office supplies** occurs **within the organisation** and does not involve an external party, so it is an **internal transaction**. The other options involve exchanges with outside parties.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a feature of transaction?

options.C: At least two parties are involved

questions.explanation: A transaction **does not only indicate profit**; it may represent losses, asset changes, settlements of liabilities, etc. A valid transaction must (1) be measurable in money, (2) involve at least two parties, and (3) affect the financial position.

questions.question: Which of the following shall not constitute a transaction?

options.C: He accepted an order for the supply of merchandise worth Tk. 25,000
options.D: Repaid salary to his manager amounting Tk. 10,000

questions.explanation: **Accepting an order** is only a **promise/commitment**; no goods or cash have yet changed hands. It is therefore **not a completed transaction** for accounting purposes. The other options all involve actual exchanges with monetary effect.

questions.question: Which of the following is treated as internal transaction?
questions.explanation: **Depreciation** is recorded internally to allocate the cost of machinery over its useful life. It does not involve any external party or cash flow, so it is an **internal transaction**.

questions.question: On December 15, 2008, Uttara Company received an order from a customer for services to be performed on December 28, 2008. Due to backlog of orders, the company could not perform the service until January 3, 2009. The customer sent a cheque for the performed services on January 6, 2009. Uttara Company received the cheque on January 8, 2009 and encashed it on January 10, 2009. In this case, when should Uttara Company record the service revenue (under accrual basis)?
questions.explanation: Under **accrual accounting**, revenue is recognised when the **service is performed** or goods are delivered, regardless of when cash is received. The service was performed on **January 3, 2009**, so revenue is recorded on that date.

questions.question: In accrual basis accounting:

options.A: Receipts and expenses are recorded when incurred
options.B: Receipts and expenses are recorded when paid
options.C: When services are rendered or products sold, and expenses are incurred are recorded
options.D: When services are rendered or products sold, and expenses paid are recorded

questions.explanation: In the **accrual basis**, - Revenue is recorded when it is **earned** (services rendered or products sold). - Expenses are recorded when they are **incurred**, not necessarily when cash is paid. So option **C** correctly describes the accrual basis.

questions.question: Cash basis of accounting is:

options.A: All transactions will be made in cash
options.B: To record in book of accounts only when cash receipts and cash payments take place
options.C: To measure all transactions in cash

questions.explanation: Under the **cash basis**, transactions are recorded **only when cash is received or paid**. Revenues are recognised when cash is collected and expenses when cash is paid, regardless of when they are earned or incurred.

questions.question: Revenue implies:

options.C: Inflow of resources but not necessarily cash
options.D: Inflow of resources and must be in cash
options.E: Inflow of resources not necessarily cash in exchange of goods or services provided to customer

questions.explanation: **Revenue** is the **inflow of resources** (not necessarily cash) that arises from providing goods or services to customers. It can be earned through cash sales, credit sales, or other forms of consideration.

questions.question: Which of the following sets of accounts normally has credit balance?
questions.explanation: The following accounts normally have **credit balances**: - **Revenue** (increases equity) - **Liabilities** (obligations) - **Capital/Equity** (owner’s interest) Therefore, the correct set is **Revenue, Liabilities, Capital**.

questions.question: Accumulated depreciation is:
questions.explanation: **Accumulated Depreciation** is a **contra-asset account** that reduces the carrying (book) value of fixed assets on the balance sheet. It shows the total depreciation charged to date.

questions.question: Accounts that normally have debit balances are:

options.B: Assets, expenses and paid up capital
options.E: Assets, profit and loss appropriation and expenses

questions.explanation: Accounts with **normal debit balances** are: - **Assets** - **Expenses** - **Dividends/Drawings** Therefore, the correct combination is **Assets, Expenses and Dividends**.

questions.question: Accumulated depreciation is an example of:
questions.explanation: Accumulated Depreciation is a **contra account** (specifically, a contra-asset account) that offsets the related asset account by showing the total depreciation accumulated over the asset’s life.

questions.question: Expense accounts:

options.A: Eventually increase the balance of the Retained Earnings account
options.C: Show the costs associated with producing revenues during an accounting period

questions.explanation: Expense accounts: - Represent the **costs incurred to generate revenues** during a period. - Normally have **debit** balances. - **Reduce** retained earnings rather than increase it. Therefore, only option **C** is correct.

questions.section: Accounting Equation & Transaction Analysis (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: During 2011 Square Pharmaceuticals Ltd.'s assets are decreased by Tk. 50,000 and liabilities are also decreased by Tk. 90,000. Its owners' equity, therefore, is:
questions.explanation: Change in Owner's Equity = Change in Assets − Change in Liabilities = (−50,000) − (−90,000) = +40,000. So owner's equity increased by Tk. 40,000.

questions.section: Accounting Equation & Transaction Analysis (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: Which of the following is the expanded form of accounting equation?

options.A: Assets + Liabilities = Owner's capital + Owner's drawing + Revenue + Expenses
options.B: Assets = Liabilities + Owner's capital + Owner's drawing + Revenue − Expenses
options.C: Assets = Liabilities − Owner's capital − Owner's drawing − Revenue − Expenses
options.D: Assets = Liabilities + Owner's capital − Owner's drawing + Revenue − Expenses
options.E: Assets + Liabilities = Owner's capital − Owner's drawing + Revenue − Expenses

questions.explanation: Expanded accounting equation for a sole trader: Assets = Liabilities + Capital − Drawings + Revenues − Expenses. This matches option D.

questions.section: Accounting Equation & Transaction Analysis (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: If Tk. 100 is stolen from the cash of a business, what will be its impact on accounts?

options.A: Decrease in cash, increase in expenses
options.B: Increase in cash, increase in expenses
options.C: Decrease in cash, increase in expenses
options.D: Increase in cash, decrease in expenses

questions.explanation: When cash is stolen, the Cash account decreases and a loss is recognised as an expense (e.g., Theft Loss). So assets (cash) go down and expenses go up, reducing equity.

questions.section: Accounting Equation & Transaction Analysis (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: Which of the following effects will the sale of goods on account have on the basic accounting equation?

options.A: Increase in assets and decrease in owner's equity
options.B: Increase in assets and increase in owner's equity
options.C: Decrease in assets and increase in liabilities
options.D: Increase in assets and increase in liabilities
options.E: No change in assets, liabilities and owner's equity

questions.explanation: Sale on account (credit sale) increases **Accounts Receivable** (asset) and **Sales Revenue**. Revenue increases owner's equity. So both assets and owner's equity increase.

questions.section: Accounting Equation & Transaction Analysis (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: The relationship among assets, liabilities and capital is expressed through:
questions.explanation: The **accounting equation** (Assets = Liabilities + Owner's Equity) directly expresses the relationship among assets, liabilities, and capital.

questions.section: Accounting Equation & Transaction Analysis (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: A transaction caused a decrease of Tk. 10,000 in both total assets and total liabilities. This transaction could have been:

options.A: A cash purchase of a printer for Tk. 10,000
options.B: Destroy of an asset by fire costing Tk. 10,000
options.C: A repayment of Tk. 10,000 bank loan
options.D: A collection of Tk. 10,000 account receivable
options.E: A purchase of goods on credit

questions.explanation: Repaying a bank loan reduces **Cash** (asset) by Tk. 10,000 and reduces **Loan Payable** (liability) by Tk. 10,000. Both sides decrease equally, keeping the equation balanced.

questions.section: Accounting Equation & Transaction Analysis (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: Identify the correct reason for the decrease in owners' equity:

options.A: Drawings and a decrease in cash
options.B: Expenses and an increase in liability
options.C: Drawings and an increase in expense
options.D: Expenses and a decrease in liability
options.E: Drawings and a decrease in liability

questions.explanation: Both **drawings** and **expenses** reduce owner's equity. Drawings are withdrawals by the owner, and expenses reduce profit. Option C combines two items that both decrease equity.

questions.section: Accounting Equation & Transaction Analysis (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: When services are provided on credit, the effect would be:

options.A: Both cash and owner's capital decrease
options.B: Both cash and owner's capital increase
options.C: Both accounts receivable and owner's capital increase

questions.explanation: Providing services on credit increases **Accounts Receivable** (asset) and **Service Revenue**, which increases owner's equity. So assets and equity both increase.

questions.section: Accounting Equation & Transaction Analysis (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: A business transaction always affects the:
questions.explanation: Every transaction must keep **Assets = Liabilities + Owner's Equity** in balance. So at least two elements of the accounting equation are affected each time.

questions.section: Accounting Equation & Transaction Analysis (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: On the last day of the period, Spectre Company purchased a machine at Tk. 90,000 on credit. This transaction will affect the:

options.C: Profit & Loss Account and Owner's Equity Statement

questions.explanation: The purchase increases **Machinery** (asset) and **Accounts Payable** (liability). Both appear in the **Balance Sheet** only; no income or expense is recognised at this point.

questions.section: Accounting Equation & Transaction Analysis (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: Basic accounting equation is generally expressed as:
questions.explanation: The basic accounting equation is: **Assets (A) = Liabilities (L) + Equity (E).**

questions.section: Accounting Equation & Transaction Analysis (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: Which of the following is correct?
questions.explanation: Profit increases **owner's equity (capital)** because profits retained in the business add to the owner's claim on assets.

questions.section: Accounting Equation & Transaction Analysis (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: Which of the following transactions causes total assets of the company to increase by Tk. 10,000?

options.B: Purchasing Tk. 10,000 of furniture on account

questions.explanation: Purchasing furniture on account increases **Furniture** (asset) by Tk. 10,000 and increases **Accounts Payable** (liability) by Tk. 10,000. Total assets increase by Tk. 10,000.

questions.section: Accounting Equation & Transaction Analysis (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: At the beginning of the accounting year, the balance sheet showed assets of Tk. 682 and owners' equity of Tk. 418. During the year, assets increased by Tk. 37 and liabilities decreased by Tk. 19. Owners' equity at the end of the year totaled:
questions.explanation: Change in owner's equity = Change in assets − Change in liabilities = +37 − (−19) = +56. Ending equity = 418 + 56 = Tk. 474.

questions.section: Accounting Equation & Transaction Analysis (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: Purchase from Mr. Rahman on credit. How will this transaction affect the accounting equation?

options.A: Assets and liabilities both will increase
options.B: Assets will increase and proprietorship will decrease
options.C: Liabilities will increase and proprietorship will decrease
options.D: Liabilities will decrease and proprietorship will increase

questions.explanation: Purchasing goods on credit increases **Inventory** (asset) and **Accounts Payable** (liability). Owner's equity is unchanged at the time of purchase.

questions.section: Accounting Equation & Transaction Analysis (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: The accounting equation is the result of:

options.A: Application of double entry system of recording
options.D: Application of accrual basis of recording

questions.explanation: The **double-entry system** requires that every transaction has equal debits and credits. This logic leads directly to the accounting equation: Assets = Liabilities + Equity.

questions.section: Accounting Equation & Transaction Analysis (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?

options.A: If you increase an asset you must increase liability or owner's equity
options.B: If you increase an asset you must decrease another asset
options.C: If you increase an asset account, you must increase another asset account
options.D: None of the above is correct

questions.explanation: An increase in an asset can be matched by: - An increase in a liability or equity (e.g., buying on credit), **or** - A decrease in another asset (asset swap), etc. No single pattern among A, B, or C is always true, so the correct choice is **D**.

questions.section: Accounting Fundamentals – Journal, Cash Book & Petty Cash (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: Festival bonus will be recorded as:

options.B: Salary Dr., Cash and Accrued Cr.

questions.explanation: Festival bonus is treated as a **salary expense**. When it is paid, we **debit Salary (or Salaries & Wages)** and **credit Cash/Bank**. So the correct entry is: **Salary Dr., Cash Cr.** (option C). > Note: Some earlier keys show option A, but that would mean the business is **receiving** cash and **reducing** salary expense, which is incorrect.

questions.section: Accounting Fundamentals – Journal, Cash Book & Petty Cash (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: A credit sales of Tk. 750 is made on June 13, terms 2/10, n/30. A return of Tk. 50 is granted on June 16. What is the amount received as payment in full on June 23?
questions.explanation: Net amount after return: 750 − 50 = **Tk. 700**. Since the customer pays within the **discount period (2/10)**, they get **2%** cash discount: Discount = 700 × 2% = **Tk. 14**. Amount received = 700 − 14 = **Tk. 686**.

questions.section: Accounting Fundamentals – Journal, Cash Book & Petty Cash (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: Of the account receivable from Sharif, 10% or Tk. 1,000 has been excluded. What is its account?
questions.explanation: When part of the receivable is **excluded because the customer paid early and received a reduction**, that reduction is a **cash discount**. It is not a bad debt or trade discount.

questions.section: Accounting Fundamentals – Journal, Cash Book & Petty Cash (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: If a customer returns goods sold on credit, an entry is normally made in:
questions.explanation: A **sales return on credit** does not belong in the sales journal (which records new credit sales), nor in cash journals. In this question’s framework, such returns are recorded in the **General Journal (Journal Proper)**, from where they are posted to the Sales Returns and Debtors’ accounts.

questions.section: Accounting Fundamentals – Journal, Cash Book & Petty Cash (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: Taka withdrawn from bank for business purpose. Its journal entry will be:
questions.explanation: Cash in hand **increases** and bank balance **decreases**. So we **debit Cash** and **credit Bank**: **Cash Dr., Bank Cr.**

questions.section: Accounting Fundamentals – Journal, Cash Book & Petty Cash (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: Sharif has purchased furniture on credit for Tk. 50,000. The related accounts would be:
questions.explanation: This is a **credit purchase of a non-current asset**. - **Furniture A/c** (asset) is **debited**. - The **supplier’s personal account (Vendor’s A/c)** is **credited**. Conceptually, option C (“Creditor’s A/c”) means the same thing, but the exam key uses the more specific term “Vendor’s A/c”.

questions.section: Trial Balance, Errors & Suspense Account (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: The error committed at the time of transferring a figure from the primary record to the ledger is related to:
questions.explanation: Transferring figures from the journal (or other primary books) to the ledger is the **posting** process. Any mistake made at this stage (for example, wrong amount or wrong side) is a **posting error**.

questions.section: Trial Balance, Errors & Suspense Account (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: An amount to be paid to Enam has been debited to Harun's account. What type of error is this?
questions.explanation: The amount was transferred to the **wrong personal account** when posting from the books of original entry to the ledger. That is a **posting error** (a form of error of commission).

questions.section: Trial Balance, Errors & Suspense Account (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: Which of the following is a part of the summarisation process in accounting?
questions.explanation: The accounting process has three stages: **recording**, **classifying**, and **summarising**. Preparing a **trial balance** is part of the summarising stage.

questions.section: Trial Balance, Errors & Suspense Account (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: Under the periodic inventory method, which of the following accounts appears in the trial balance as a separate account?

options.C: Cost of goods available for sale

questions.explanation: Under the **periodic** inventory system, there is a separate **Opening Inventory** (or Opening Stock) account which appears in the trial balance along with **Purchases**, etc. The **Cost of Goods Sold** account is not maintained on a continuous basis under the periodic system; it is computed only at year‑end.

questions.section: Trial Balance, Errors & Suspense Account (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: A trader of furniture purchased furniture and debited it to Purchases Account. What type of error has occurred?
questions.explanation: For a **furniture trader**, furniture is **trading stock (inventory)**, not a fixed asset. Recording the purchase in **Purchases Account** is **correct**, so no error has been made.

questions.section: Trial Balance, Errors & Suspense Account (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: Under a perpetual inventory system followed by a merchandising business, the trial balance will not show any account balance for which of the following?
questions.explanation: Under the perpetual system, inventory is kept in a single **Inventory** account that is continuously updated. There is **no separate “Opening Inventory” account**, so that item does not appear in the trial balance.

questions.section: Trial Balance, Errors & Suspense Account (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: A trial balance will not balance if:

options.A: Purchase of furniture is recorded as merchandise purchase
options.B: Salary payment is not posted to Salary Expense in the ledger
options.C: Equipment purchased on account is mistakenly debited to Purchases and credited to Cash
options.D: Prepaid insurance was mistakenly debited to Insurance Expense
options.E: A collection from a customer is credited to the account of another customer

questions.explanation: If the **cash credit** for salary is posted but the **debit to Salary Expense** is **not posted**, total credits exceed total debits, so the trial balance does **not** agree. The other choices keep debits and credits equal (they are classification or posting‑to‑wrong‑account errors), so the trial balance can still balance.

questions.section: Trial Balance, Errors & Suspense Account (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: Purchase of furniture is debited to Purchases Account. What kind of error is this (for a business where furniture is a fixed asset)?
questions.explanation: Furniture is a **capital expenditure (asset)**, but it has been recorded as a **revenue expenditure** (Purchases). This violates proper capital–revenue classification and is an **error of principle**.

questions.section: Trial Balance, Errors & Suspense Account (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: A revenue expenditure has been recorded as capital expenditure. What type of error is it?
questions.explanation: Misclassifying revenue expenditure (e.g., repairs) as a capital item (asset) breaks the rule that **capital and revenue items must be separated**, so it is an **error of principle**.

questions.section: Trial Balance, Errors & Suspense Account (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: Which of the following is not a clerical error?
questions.explanation: Clerical errors arise from mistakes in **recording or posting** (omission, commission, compensating, posting). Errors of **principle** involve **wrong application of accounting principles**, not clerical slips.

questions.section: Trial Balance, Errors & Suspense Account (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: An account balance of Tk. 80 has been recorded on the wrong side of the trial balance. All other things being correct, the difference between the two sides of the trial balance would be Tk.:
questions.explanation: Putting Tk. 80 on the wrong side has a **double effect**: - The side where it should have appeared is **short by Tk. 80**. - The opposite side is **overstated by Tk. 80**. Total difference = 80 + 80 = **Tk. 160**.

questions.section: Trial Balance, Errors & Suspense Account (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: The primary purpose of a trial balance is to:

options.A: Prove that all transactions have been recorded
options.B: Prove the mathematical accuracy of debits and credits after posting
options.C: Uncover all errors in journal and ledger
options.D: Determine the net income for the year

questions.explanation: A trial balance is prepared mainly to **test the arithmetic accuracy** of the ledger by checking that total debits **equal** total credits. It can reveal some errors, but not all.

questions.section: Trial Balance, Errors & Suspense Account (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: If trial balance totals do not agree, the difference must be entered in which account (temporarily)?
questions.explanation: A **Suspense Account** is opened to carry the difference while the errors are being investigated. Once all errors are corrected, the suspense account balance should become **zero** and be closed.

questions.section: Trial Balance, Errors & Suspense Account (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: A balance of Tk. 42 has been put on the wrong side of the trial balance. If everything else is correct, what would be the trial balance difference?
questions.explanation: Same logic as Question 11: the correct side is understated by Tk. 42 and the wrong side is overstated by Tk. 42. Total difference = 42 + 42 = **Tk. 84**.

questions.section: Trial Balance, Errors & Suspense Account (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: Which one is an error of principle?

options.A: A transaction has been omitted from being recorded
options.B: A transaction of Tk. 2,175 was recorded as Tk. 2,157
options.C: Capital expenditure has been treated as revenue expenditure

questions.explanation: Treating a **capital expenditure** (e.g., machinery) as a **revenue expense** breaks the rule of proper capital–revenue classification. This is a classic **error of principle**.

questions.section: Trial Balance, Errors & Suspense Account (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: Which of the following errors would result in disagreement of the trial balance?

options.A: Expenditure on machinery has been shown in Furniture Account
options.B: Records in the debtors’ accounts have been mistaken with one another
options.C: The debit balance of one account and the credit balance of another unrelated account have not been listed in the trial balance at all
options.D: One transaction has been omitted altogether

questions.explanation: If a **debit balance** and an unrelated **credit balance** (often of **different amounts**) are both omitted from the trial balance, the reductions on the two sides are **not equal**, so the totals will **disagree**. The other options either involve misclassification or complete omission of both sides of *a single* transaction, both of which leave total debits and credits equal.

questions.section: Trial Balance, Errors & Suspense Account (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: What should be done if the balance of the suspense account is of a substantial or material amount?

options.A: It should be written off in the Balance Sheet
options.B: Carry forward the balance to the next period
options.C: Find the error before publishing the final accounts
options.D: It should be written off in the Profit and Loss Account

questions.explanation: A large suspense account balance indicates **significant errors**. These must be **found and corrected** before the financial statements are issued; it is not acceptable simply to write off or carry forward a material suspense balance.

questions.section: Trial Balance, Errors & Suspense Account (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: Which of these errors could be disclosed by the trial balance?

options.A: A cheque of Tk. 574 from Mr. Karim entered in Karim's Account as Tk. 475
options.B: Selling expenses have been debited to Sales Account
options.C: Credit sales of Tk. 300 entered in double‑entry accounts as Tk. 30
options.D: A purchase of Tk. 250 was omitted entirely from the books

questions.explanation: If Cash is debited Tk. 574 but Karim’s account is credited Tk. 475, there is a **difference of Tk. 99** between the debit and credit. The trial balance will therefore **not agree** and will highlight this error. The other errors are either classification errors or equal understatements of both debit and credit, so the trial balance totals can still agree.

questions.section: Trial Balance, Errors & Suspense Account (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: When is a Suspense Account debited or credited in rectifying an error?
questions.explanation: Suspense accounts are used **only for one‑sided errors**, where one side of the double entry is missing and the trial balance does **not** agree. Two‑sided errors keep debits and credits equal and do not need a suspense account.

questions.section: Trial Balance, Errors & Suspense Account (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: The errors which do not affect the agreement of the trial balance include:

options.B: Error of principle and certain clerical errors

questions.explanation: Errors of principle and many **clerical errors** (such as posting to the wrong account of the same type) still record **equal debits and credits**, so the trial balance totals remain equal. Errors in addition or one‑sided posting errors usually **disturb the equality** and cause disagreement.

questions.section: Adjusting Entries & Year‑End Adjustments (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: The balance in the Rent Expense account is Tk. 5,000. At the end of the year, it is found that Tk. 2,000 of this amount relates to the next year and should be treated as prepaid. Which adjusting entry is required?

options.A: Rent account debit, Cash account credit
options.B: Prepaid Rent account debit, Rent account credit
options.C: Cash account debit, Rent account credit
options.D: Cash account debit, Prepaid Rent account credit
options.E: Rent account debit, Prepaid Rent account credit

questions.explanation: Out of Tk. 5,000 initially charged as expense, Tk. 2,000 belongs to **next year**, so it must be **removed from expense** and carried as a **prepaid asset**: - **Prepaid Rent Dr. 2,000** - **Rent Expense Cr. 2,000** This leaves Rent Expense for the current year = 5,000 − 2,000 = 3,000, and Prepaid Rent (asset) = 2,000.

questions.section: Adjusting Entries & Year‑End Adjustments (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: If the adjusting entry for unearned revenue is not made, then:
questions.explanation: When cash received in advance is recorded as **Unearned Revenue (liability)**, an adjustment is needed to transfer the **earned portion** to Revenue. If this adjustment is omitted, the **liability remains too high** (overstated) and revenue is understated.

questions.section: Adjusting Entries & Year‑End Adjustments (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: Supplies account shows a balance of Tk. 10,000. At year‑end, Tk. 6,000 of supplies remain unused. What is the adjusting entry?

options.A: Supplies Expense Dr. Tk. 6,000; Supplies Cr. Tk. 6,000
options.B: Supplies Dr. Tk. 10,000; Supplies Expense Cr. Tk. 6,000
options.C: Supplies Dr. Tk. 4,000; Supplies Expense Cr. Tk. 6,000
options.D: Supplies Expense Dr. Tk. 4,000; Cash Cr. Tk. 4,000
options.E: Supplies Expense Dr. Tk. 4,000; Supplies Cr. Tk. 4,000

questions.explanation: Supplies **used** during the year = 10,000 − 6,000 = **Tk. 4,000**. So we transfer this amount to expense: **Supplies Expense Dr. 4,000; Supplies Cr. 4,000**.

questions.section: Adjusting Entries & Year‑End Adjustments (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: If accounts are not adjusted before preparation of financial statements, the effect on net income will be:
questions.explanation: Some missed adjustments (like prepaid expenses or depreciation) cause **expenses to be understated**, so net income is **overstated**. Others (like unrecorded accrued revenues) cause revenues to be understated, so net income is **understated**. Overall, net income may go **either way**.

questions.section: Adjusting Entries & Year‑End Adjustments (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: Revenue that is earned but not collected in cash is called:
questions.explanation: Income that has been **earned** but not yet received or recorded is **accrued revenue** (e.g., interest receivable, rent receivable). It requires an adjusting entry: Asset (Receivable) Dr; Revenue Cr.

questions.section: Adjusting Entries & Year‑End Adjustments (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: What happens when adjusting entries are made at the end of the accounting period?

options.A: They always involve at least two balance sheet accounts
options.B: They always adjust the Cash account
options.C: They always involve at least one income statement account and one balance sheet account
options.D: They always adjust at least two income statement accounts
options.E: None of the above is correct

questions.explanation: Adjusting entries always link **income statement accounts** (revenues or expenses) with **balance sheet accounts** (assets, liabilities, or equity) to achieve proper matching and correct ending balances.

questions.section: Adjusting Entries & Year‑End Adjustments (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: The adjustment for depreciation expense is to:
questions.explanation: Depreciation is recorded by: **Depreciation Expense Dr.; Accumulated Depreciation Cr.** This **increases expense** and **increases a contra‑asset**, thereby **reducing net assets**.

questions.section: Adjusting Entries & Year‑End Adjustments (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: Supplies on hand on January 1 are Tk. 350. Supplies purchased during the year are Tk. 675. Supplies remaining at year‑end are Tk. 250. What is Supplies Expense for the year?
questions.explanation: Supplies Expense = Opening supplies + Purchases − Closing supplies = 350 + 675 − 250 = **Tk. 775**.

questions.section: Adjusting Entries & Year‑End Adjustments (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: The adjusting entry for accrued expenses affects:
questions.explanation: Accrued expenses are **incurred but unpaid**. The adjustment is: **Expense Dr.; Accrued Liability (Payable) Cr.** So **expenses and liabilities** both increase.

questions.section: Adjusting Entries & Year‑End Adjustments (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: Which one of the following can be considered as a prepayment?

options.B: Payment of two years’ office rent in the first year

questions.explanation: Paying **two years’ rent in advance** creates a **prepaid expense** (asset). The payment will be expensed gradually over the rental period.

questions.section: Adjusting Entries & Year‑End Adjustments (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: The journal entry for “interest earned but not yet received” will be:

options.C: Interest Receivable Dr.; Interest Income Cr.
options.D: Interest Payable Dr.; Interest Income Cr.
options.E: Interest Income Dr.; Interest Receivable Cr.

questions.explanation: Accrued interest increases an **asset** and **revenue**: **Interest Receivable Dr.; Interest Income Cr.**

questions.section: Adjusting Entries & Year‑End Adjustments (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: The journal entry for “cash payment for insurance to cover a three‑year period” will be:
questions.explanation: Paying in advance for three years of coverage creates a **prepaid insurance asset**: **Prepaid Insurance Dr.; Cash Cr.**

questions.section: Adjusting Entries & Year‑End Adjustments (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: An investment of Tk. 60,000 was made in 2005 for 8 years at an interest rate of 10% per year. On December 31, an adjusting entry for accrued interest revenue of Tk. 3,500 was made. No cash interest was received during the year. The investment was made on:
questions.explanation: Annual interest = 60,000 × 10% = **Tk. 6,000** Monthly interest = 6,000 ÷ 12 = **Tk. 500** Accrued interest = 3,500 → Months = 3,500 ÷ 500 = **7 months** Seven months before December 31 is **June 1**, so the investment was made on June 1. (The original key showing July 1 is incorrect.)

questions.section: Adjusting Entries & Year‑End Adjustments (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: At the end of the fiscal year, the adjusting entry for accrued salaries was inadvertently omitted. The effect of this error will be:

options.A: Understatement of expenses for the year
options.B: Overstatement of net income for the year
options.C: Understatement of liabilities at the end of the year
options.D: Overstatement of tax for the year

questions.explanation: Without recording accrued salaries: - **Expenses are understated** (A), - Therefore **net income is overstated** (B), - The unpaid salaries (a liability) are **not recorded** (C), and - If tax is based on the overstated income, **tax expense is overstated** (D). Thus, **all statements are correct**.

questions.section: Adjusting Entries & Year‑End Adjustments (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: If the debit portion of a specific adjusting entry increases an asset account, the effect of the credit portion of the entry would normally be to:
questions.explanation: Among the standard types of adjusting entries, the case where the **debit increases an asset** is typically **accrued revenue** (e.g., interest receivable). The credit in such an entry is to **Revenue**, so revenue increases.

questions.section: Adjusting Entries & Year‑End Adjustments (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: At the end of its 2000 fiscal year, Medona Ltd. omitted an adjustment to record Tk. 20,000 of accrued service revenues. As a result of this error there has been:

options.A: Overstatement of net income by Tk. 20,000 for the period
options.B: Overstatement of revenue by Tk. 20,000 for the period
options.C: Understatement of revenue and total assets by Tk. 20,000 respectively
options.D: Overstatement of total assets by Tk. 20,000 on that day
options.E: No effect in the financial statements

questions.explanation: Without the accrued revenue entry, both **Revenue** (income statement) and the related **Receivable (asset)** are **understated by Tk. 20,000**.

questions.section: Adjusting Entries & Year‑End Adjustments (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: A 3‑year insurance policy was purchased in 1998 for Tk. 3,600 and debited to Prepaid Insurance. It was discovered in 1999 that no entry had been made with regard to the insurance in 1998 and therefore 1998 net income had been overstated by Tk. 1,000. The date of purchasing the policy was:
questions.explanation: Total term = 3 years = 36 months, total cost = 3,600 → **Tk. 100 per month**. If 1998 income was overstated by **Tk. 1,000**, then **10 months** of expense were omitted. Counting 10 months back from 31 December 1998 → policy started on **1 March 1998**.

questions.section: Adjusting Entries & Year‑End Adjustments (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: From the following entries, which one is not a major adjusting entry?
questions.explanation: The four major types of adjusting entries are: 1. **Prepaid (deferred) expenses** 2. **Unearned (deferred) revenues** 3. **Accrued expenses** 4. **Accrued revenues** “**Earned revenue**” is just ordinary revenue; it is not a separate category of adjusting entry.

questions.section: Adjusting Entries & Year‑End Adjustments (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: Which of the following is an example of an adjusting entry?

options.A: Recording the purchase of supplies on account
options.B: Recording depreciation expense on a truck
options.C: Recording billings to customers for services rendered
options.D: Recording the payment of wages to employees

questions.explanation: Depreciation is recorded at **period‑end** to allocate the cost of a non‑current asset over its useful life. It is a classic **adjusting entry**. The other options are normal day‑to‑day transactions.

questions.section: Adjusting Entries & Year‑End Adjustments (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: The trial balance shows Supplies Tk. 1,350 and Supplies Expense Tk. 0. If Tk. 800 of supplies is on hand at the end of the period, the adjusting entry is:

options.A: Supplies Dr. Tk. 550; Supplies Expense Cr. Tk. 550
options.B: Supplies Expense Dr. Tk. 550; Supplies Cr. Tk. 550
options.C: Supplies Expense Dr. Tk. 800; Supplies Cr. Tk. 800

questions.explanation: Supplies used = 1,350 − 800 = **Tk. 550**. We transfer this to expense: **Supplies Expense Dr. 550; Supplies Cr. 550**.

questions.section: Adjusting Entries & Year‑End Adjustments (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: Why are adjusting entries necessary?

options.A: Because many transactions affect more than one accounting period
options.C: To close nominal accounts at year‑end
options.D: To correct erroneous balances in accounts

questions.explanation: Many items (rent, insurance, depreciation, accrued wages, etc.) relate to **more than one period**. Adjusting entries allocate these correctly between periods to satisfy the **accrual and matching principles**.

questions.section: Adjusting Entries & Year‑End Adjustments (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: An example of an adjusting entry is:
questions.explanation: **Interest accruing** (without cash being received) is recorded via an adjusting entry: **Interest Receivable Dr.; Interest Income Cr.** The payment of accrued wages and advance rent are normal cash transactions, not adjusting entries.

questions.section: Adjusting Entries & Year‑End Adjustments (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: Which of the following statements is most acceptable?

options.A: Every adjusting entry affects both the balance sheet and the income statement
options.B: Adjusting entries do not affect owner's equity
options.C: Adjusting entries affect the balance sheet only
options.D: Adjusting entries affect the income statement only

questions.explanation: Each adjusting entry links one **income statement** account (revenue or expense) with one **balance sheet** account (asset, liability, or equity). Thus it affects **both** financial statements.

questions.section: Adjusting Entries & Year‑End Adjustments (DU Past Questions)
questions.question: The entry to record an accrual of wages expense is:

options.A: Wages Expense A/C Dr.; Assets A/C Cr.
options.B: Wages Expense A/C Dr.; Wages Payable A/C Cr.
options.C: Assets A/C Dr.; Wages Expense A/C Cr.
options.D: Wages Payable A/C Dr.; Wages Expense A/C Cr.

questions.explanation: To record wages incurred but unpaid: **Wages Expense Dr.; Wages Payable Cr.** This increases the **expense** and recognises the **liability**.
