questions.question: If the net profit of a firm is Tk. 6,000 and tax rate is 40%, then the amount of profit before tax will be:
questions.explanation: Net profit after tax = Tk. 6,000 Tax rate = 40% Net profit represents **60%** of profit before tax (100% − 40%). So, \[ 0.60 \times \text{Profit before tax} = 6,000 \] \[ \text{Profit before tax} = \frac{6,000}{0.60} = 10,000 \] Check: - Tax = 10,000 × 40% = 4,000 - Net profit = 10,000 − 4,000 = 6,000 ✓

questions.question: What type of item is the VAT on sales?
questions.explanation: VAT collected on sales is **not income** of the business. The firm collects it on behalf of the government and must later pay it to the tax authority. Therefore, VAT on sales is recorded as a **liability (VAT Payable)** until it is remitted.

questions.question: After deducting commission of partner Y at the rate of 5% on net profit after commission, Y received Tk. 1,000 as his commission. He is an equal partner with X and Z. How much will Y get as his share of profit (excluding commission) from the partnership?
questions.explanation: Let **P** = profit **before** Y’s commission. Y’s commission = 5% of (P − commission) Given commission = 1,000: \[ 1,000 = 0.05 (P - 1,000) \] \[ 1,000 = 0.05P - 50 \Rightarrow 1,050 = 0.05P \Rightarrow P = 21,000 \] Divisible profit **after** commission: \[ P - \text{commission} = 21,000 - 1,000 = 20,000 \] Partners X, Y, Z share profits equally: \[ \text{Y’s share of profit} = \frac{20,000}{3} \approx 6,666.67 \approx \mathbf{6,667} \] (Commission of Tk. 1,000 is **extra** and not part of this 6,667.)

questions.question: If the net income of a firm is Tk. 5,000 and the tax rate is 40%, then the amount of profit before tax is:
questions.explanation: Net income after tax = Tk. 5,000 Tax rate = 40% Net income represents **60%** of profit before tax. \[ 0.60 \times \text{Profit before tax} = 5,000 \] \[ \text{Profit before tax} = \frac{5,000}{0.60} \approx 8,333.33 \approx \mathbf{8,333} \] Check: - Tax ≈ 8,333 × 40% ≈ 3,333 - Net income ≈ 8,333 − 3,333 ≈ 5,000 ✓

questions.question: Credit sales of Tk. 600 were credited to the Sales Account and to the Debtors Account. What is its effect?

options.A: Debtors account will be reduced by Tk. 1,200
options.B: Creditors account will be reduced by Tk. 600
options.C: Profit will be reduced by Tk. 1,200
options.D: Profit will be overstated by Tk. 600
options.E: Sales account and Debtors account will be affected equally

questions.explanation: Correct entry for a credit sale of Tk. 600 is: - **Dr Debtors 600** - **Cr Sales 600** What was actually done: - Cr Sales 600 ✅ (correct) - Cr Debtors 600 ❌ (should have been debit) Effect on Debtors: - Should be **Dr 600** but is **Cr 600** - Difference from correct position = 600 (missing debit) + 600 (wrong credit) = **1,200** So the Debtors balance is **understated by Tk. 1,200** (i.e., “reduced by Tk. 1,200” compared with the correct balance). Rectification (not asked, but useful): - Dr Debtors 1,200 - Cr Suspense 1,200

questions.question: An amount of Tk. 12,800 paid for salary was recorded in the books as Tk. 18,200. The correcting entry would be:
questions.explanation: Correct entry (what should have been recorded): - Salary Dr 12,800 - Cash Cr 12,800 Wrong entry recorded: - Salary Dr 18,200 - Cash Cr 18,200 Both Salary and Cash are **overstated** by: \[ 18,200 - 12,800 = 5,400 \] To remove the excess: - **Dr Cash 5,400** → decreases the over‑credited Cash - **Cr Salary 5,400** → decreases the over‑debited Salary So the correcting entry is: > Cash A/C Dr 5,400 > Salary A/C Cr 5,400

questions.question: A sales return has wrongly been recorded in the Purchases Day Book. What is the correct rectification entry?

options.D: Suspense Account Debit; Sales Returns Credit

questions.explanation: Correct treatment of a sales return: - **Dr Sales Returns** - **Cr Debtor (customer)** Wrong treatment (Purchases Day Book used): - **Dr Purchases** - **Cr Debtor** To rectify, we: 1. Cancel the wrong debit to Purchases by **crediting Purchases**. 2. Record the correct debit to Sales Returns by **debiting Sales Returns**. So the rectifying entry is: > Sales Returns A/C Dr > To Purchases A/C

questions.question: Tk. 100 received from Karim was debited to Karim’s account. The journal entry to rectify this error is:

options.A: Suspense A/C Dr. Tk. 200; Karim A/C Cr. Tk. 200
options.B: Karim A/C Dr. Tk. 100; Suspense A/C Cr. Tk. 100
options.C: Suspense A/C Dr. Tk. 100; Karim A/C Cr. Tk. 100
options.D: Karim A/C Dr. Tk. 200; Suspense A/C Cr. Tk. 200

questions.explanation: Correct entry for cash received from a debtor (Karim): - **Dr Cash 100** - **Cr Karim 100** Wrong entry passed: - **Dr Karim 100** - (Likely Cr Cash 100 – but Karim’s side is definitely wrong) So, in Karim’s account: - Should have been **Cr 100** - Actually **Dr 100** Total adjustment required = 100 (to cancel wrong debit) + 100 (to create correct credit) = **Tk. 200** credit. Rectification (using Suspense for the other side): > Suspense A/C Dr 200 > To Karim A/C Cr 200 This removes the incorrect debit of 100 and records the correct credit of 100, resulting in a net 200‑credit swing in Karim’s account.

lectures.title: DU FBS Accounting – Lecture 12 MCQs
lectures.topics: Capital & Revenue Income–Expenditure, Single Entry System (Incomplete Records), Cash Flow Statement, Introduction to Managerial Accounting

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of deferred revenue expenditure?
questions.explanation: **Deferred revenue expenditure** is a (large) revenue-type expense whose benefit is expected to last for **several future periods**, so it is written off gradually. Classical textbook examples include: - **Preliminary (formation) expenses**, - **Discount on issue of debentures/shares**, - Heavy advertising campaigns, etc. Prepaid rent (A) is a **prepaid expense (current asset)** covering only the next period or so, not a multi‑year heavy outlay. Depreciation (B) is an **allocation of asset cost**, not an expenditure itself. Among the options, the most standard example of deferred revenue expenditure is **preliminary expenses**. *(Note: Discount on debentures (D) is also often treated as a deferred revenue expenditure, but DU‑style MCQs usually expect “Preliminary expenses” here.)*

questions.question: Where will you report the capital expenditure?
questions.explanation: Capital expenditure is spent to **acquire or improve long‑term assets** (land, building, machinery, etc.). Such costs are **capitalized** as assets in the Balance Sheet and then depreciated over time. Only the depreciation charge appears in the Profit & Loss Account. Therefore, capital expenditure itself is shown on the **asset side of the Balance Sheet**.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a deferred revenue expenditure?

options.B: Expenditure on shifting of a factory
options.D: Expenditure on formation of a company
options.E: Advertisement expenditure of a large amount

questions.explanation: Items such as **major repairs**, **factory shifting cost**, **company formation cost** and **heavy advertisement** all give benefit over several years and can be treated as **deferred revenue expenditure**. - Interest on loan (C) is a **regular revenue expense** relating only to the current period and must be charged fully to the Profit & Loss Account in that year, so it is **not** deferred revenue expenditure.

questions.question: Addition to the plant assets is:
questions.explanation: An addition to plant assets **increases productive capacity** or extends the useful life of the asset. It provides benefit for more than one accounting period, so it is treated as **capital expenditure** and added to the asset cost on the Balance Sheet.

questions.question: Which one of the following is an example of capital income?
questions.explanation: **Capital income** arises from transactions involving **capital assets or capital structure**, not from normal trading operations. - **Sale of machinery (B)** is the disposal of a fixed asset, so the gain is capital in nature. - Sale of wastage/scrap (D) is usually **other revenue income** arising from normal operations. - Revaluation surplus (E) is an **unrealised capital gain**, usually credited to a revaluation reserve, not taken as income. - Income before incorporation (A) and income from forfeiture of shares (C) are treated as capital profits, but among the options the clearest example of **capital income** that is actually realised as cash is **sale of machinery**.

questions.question: Which is revenue expenditure?
questions.explanation: Costs **necessary to bring a machine to its working condition and location** (purchase price, freight, carriage inwards, installation wages, VAT, etc.) are **capitalized** as part of the asset cost. Insurance of the machine is a **recurring operating expense** providing benefit only for the current period, so it is **revenue expenditure**.

questions.question: Which of the following items, although related to the purchase of a fixed asset, is not capitalized?

options.B: Freight and insurance cost paid for the machinery
options.C: Salaries and wages paid for installing the machinery
options.D: VAT @ 10% paid on the price of the machinery

questions.explanation: The **cost of the asset** includes purchase price plus all costs necessary to bring it to working condition and location (A–D), so all of those are capitalized. **Scrap value** (residual value) is an **estimate of what will be received at the end of the asset’s life**; it is **not** an initial cost and is therefore **not capitalized**. It is only used when computing depreciation.

questions.question: An advertisement expense which will be fruitful for four years—what kind of expense is it?
questions.explanation: A heavy advertisement campaign that is expected to benefit the business for several years is: - not a capital asset, but - its benefit extends beyond one accounting period. It is therefore treated as **deferred revenue expenditure**, and the cost is amortized over the four years of benefit.

questions.question: Which one of the following is revenue expenditure?

options.B: Cost of depreciation of leasehold property
options.C: Legal expenses in connection with acquiring leasehold property
options.D: Wages for the installation of a new machine

questions.explanation: - The **cost of acquiring** leasehold property and legal expenses to acquire it (A and C), and installation wages for a new machine (D), are all **capital expenditure**. - **Depreciation** on the leasehold property (B) is a **recurring allocation of that capital cost**, charged each year to the Profit & Loss Account, so it is **revenue expenditure**.

questions.question: Beginning capital Tk. 2,00,000, investment during the year Tk. 3,00,000, owner's drawing Tk. 50,000 and closing capital Tk. 7,00,000. What is the profit during the year in Taka?
questions.explanation: Use the capital comparison formula: \[ \text{Profit} = \text{Closing capital} + \text{Drawings} - \text{Opening capital} - \text{Additional capital} \] \[ = 7,00,000 + 50,000 - 2,00,000 - 3,00,000 = 7,50,000 - 5,00,000 = \mathbf{2,50,000} \] So the profit for the year is Tk. 2,50,000.

questions.question: A businessman maintains incomplete records. At the beginning of 2005, his capital was Tk. 56,000 and at the end of 2005, the balance of his capital account stood at Tk. 1,20,000. In the same year, the businessman supplied equipment worth Tk. 30,000 to his business and withdrew Tk. 14,000 worth of materials from his business for personal use. What was his profit or loss in Taka for the year 2005?
questions.explanation: Additional investment (equipment supplied) = 30,000 Drawings (materials withdrawn) = 14,000 \[ \text{Profit} = 1,20,000 + 14,000 - 56,000 - 30,000 = 1,34,000 - 86,000 = \mathbf{48,000} \] So the business earned a profit of Tk. 48,000.

questions.question: Which of the following can be a correct description of an incomplete record?

options.A: An admixture of single entry and no entry
options.B: An admixture of single entry, double entry and no entry
options.C: An admixture of double entry and no entry
options.D: An admixture of double entry and wrong entry
options.E: An admixture of wrong entry, double entry, no entry and single entry

questions.explanation: Under **incomplete records (single entry system)**: - Some transactions are recorded with **double entry**, - Some with **only one side recorded (single entry)**, - Some transactions are **not recorded at all**. So it is essentially a mixture of **single entry, double entry and no entry**.

questions.question: The beginning capital of Sheba Co. was Tk. 3,30,000 and the capital at the end stood at Tk. 4,50,000. During the year total revenue was Tk. 95,000 and total expense was Tk. 60,000. Additional capital investment was Tk. 1,05,000. The amount of drawings by the owner during the period was Tk.:
questions.explanation: First compute profit: \[ \text{Profit} = \text{Revenue} - \text{Expense} = 95,000 - 60,000 = 35,000 \] Now apply: \[ \text{Closing capital} = \text{Opening capital} + \text{Additional investment} + \text{Profit} - \text{Drawings} \] \[ 4,50,000 = 3,30,000 + 1,05,000 + 35,000 - \text{Drawings} = 4,70,000 - \text{Drawings} \] \[ \text{Drawings} = 4,70,000 - 4,50,000 = \mathbf{20,000} \]

questions.question: At the beginning of the year the total assets and liabilities of an enterprise were Tk. 3,00,000 and Tk. 1,00,000 respectively. During the year, owner has invested Tk. 50,000 and withdrawn Tk. 1,00,000. At the end of the year, closing capital rises by 20% in comparison with the beginning. The profit or loss for the year was Tk.:

In 2002 a small business firm had initial capital of Tk. 2,20,000. Closing capital was Tk. 1,40,000. In the middle of the year additional capital of Tk. 30,000 was invested. During the same period the owner withdrew Tk. 15,000 from the business. What was the total loss or gain in the year of 2002?

A business had the following amounts of assets and liabilities at the beginning and end of a recent year: Assets (Beginning) Tk. 1,50,000, Liabilities (Beginning) Tk. 60,000, Assets (End) Tk. 2,40,000, Liabilities (End) Tk. 92,000. Determine the net income earned or net loss incurred by the business during the year under the following assumptions: The owner made no additional investment in the business during the year but withdrew Tk. 3,500 per month to pay personal living expenses.
If opening capital is Tk. 16,500, additional capital is Tk. 3,700, closing capital is Tk. 11,350 and drawings are Tk. 3,300, then what will be the amount of profit or loss for the year?

A retailer who does not keep books under double entry system had: Fixed Assets (1.1.1998) Tk. 25,000, Current Assets (1.1.1998) Tk. 54,000, Total Liabilities (1.1.1998) Tk. 23,000, Fixed Assets (31.12.1998) Tk. 30,000, Current Assets (31.12.1998) Tk. 77,000, Total Liabilities (31.12.1998) Tk. 32,000. During 1998, he introduced Tk. 6,000 as fresh capital and withdrew Tk. 11,000 for personal use. What is the amount of profit he earned during 1998?

The ending balance of owner's capital was Tk. 21,000. During that year, the owner contributed Tk. 6,000 and withdrew Tk. 4,000. If the firm had Tk. 8,000 net income for the year, what was the beginning owner's capital?
questions.explanation: Re‑arrange the capital formula to find opening capital: \[ \text{Opening capital} = \text{Closing capital} + \text{Drawings} - \text{Additional capital} - \text{Profit} \] \[ = 21,000 + 4,000 - 6,000 - 8,000 = 25,000 - 14,000 = \mathbf{11,000} \]

questions.question: A sole trader had on 1 January 1990 assets of Tk. 50,000 and liabilities of Tk. 25,000 and on 31 December 1990 assets of Tk. 65,000 and liabilities of Tk. 17,000. He has earned profit during the year:
questions.explanation: Opening capital: \[ = 50,000 - 25,000 = 25,000 \] Closing capital: \[ = 65,000 - 17,000 = 48,000 \] Assuming no drawings or additional capital: \[ \text{Profit} = 48,000 - 25,000 = \mathbf{23,000} \]

questions.question: What kind of cash flow is the sale of old furniture?
questions.explanation: Old furniture is a **fixed asset**. Cash received from its sale is a cash inflow from **investing activities**, because investing activities include acquisition and disposal of long‑term assets (property, plant and equipment). It is not an operating or financing cash flow.

questions.question: What is the main reason for preparing the statement of cash flow?

options.A: To agree with the Company Acts
options.B: To show the financial position of the Company
options.C: To show the profit and loss of the Company
options.D: To show the sources and uses of cash
options.E: To know the amount of cash to be shown on a balance sheet

questions.explanation: The **primary purpose** of the cash flow statement is to show: - from **where** cash was generated (sources/inflows), and - **how** it was used (outflows), classified into operating, investing and financing activities. The Balance Sheet already shows financial position and the Income Statement shows profit or loss; the cash flow statement focuses specifically on **cash movements** and liquidity.

questions.question: Which of the following information is unnecessary to determine the breakeven point of a company?
questions.explanation: To compute **breakeven point (BEP)** you need: - **Fixed costs**, - **Variable cost per unit** (or contribution margin per unit), and - **Selling price per unit**. Contribution margin per unit = Selling price − Variable cost per unit. BEP (units) = Fixed costs ÷ Contribution margin per unit. **Average cost** (total cost ÷ units) changes with volume and is **not** required for BEP calculations, so it is unnecessary here.
